those people are alive today why because they didn't have access perhaps you know
there was not someone there to give them CPR and no access to a defibrillator if
the phone could become a defibrillator we wouldn't have that problem and people
who are living without their loved ones today would have their loved ones with them you know imagine if the medicine

people say what is precision medicine really mean and what precision medicine really means is that your care and
treatment including your medications are appropriate for you and your biology and
your genetics and the environment that you live in when you go to the eye doctor you generally walk away with a
set of eyeglasses that allow you magically to see because there's a prescription that has been developed

in the world for that that so many people and caused heart attacks and strokes and early onset Alzheimer's and

all there's a period of trial and error to figure out which combination of drugs
are going to work for you and for many people the side effects of blood pressure medication make them feel worse

pressure than to have the side effects of medication until of course you drop over from a stroke or a heart attack and
so with the focus on precision medicine it is finding the right treatment at the right time for the right patient and if
we could really make this happen in cardiovascular diseases we would change the world and change lives for so
many people you know imagine if nanobots
in your blood could alert you to a cardiovascular event before it happened there are people working on this
research right now you know there are so many smart people because they are also
not just great scientists but they understand and know how to use technology that are creating these

attack or a stroke or some other health episode and so we look at all of these

together could truly change the world and to my point about lack of access to

even here in the United States people in rural communities who suffer devastating
events do not often have access to state-of-the-art special so here a lot about telemedicine we've done some of
the pioneering work in telemedicine and stroke as an aside if a person is having
a stroke caused by a blood clot in the brain if the miracle drug TPA is
administered in a 90-minute window that person will walk out of the hospital in days as if the stroke never happened now
there are these new clot retrievers again it requires the stroke to be diagnosed early and so it's great it's
not great but if you have a stroke it is more fortunate for you if you have the stroke in a major city right here in
Seattle I'm sure that there are certified comprehensive stroke centers ready to use these state-of-the-art
techniques but if you're in a rural area you may not be 90 minutes near a
physician that's able to diagnose this or even if you have a simple health problem imagine how your life could be
changed if all of this new technology could allow you access to any healthcare provider in the world and so at the
American Heart Association we think about all of this possibility and how will it help us achieve our bold goals
for the future and I don't just mean this year I mean now in the next 10 years and so the strategic focus areas
of the h.a include accelerating science through technology transforming
communities were so many disparities and access to health and health care and healthy places to live are so visible in
this country and in this world we want to improve systems of care so that
people can get to the right healthcare system at the right time and we want to empower consumers so that they can be
focused on overall health and well-being and these are really the things that we're doing at the American Heart
Association today and we do these by focusing on the things that we believe differentiate us from any other
